description.narrative:
Bangladesh is one of the most climate- vulnerable countries , and the challenge of climate change poses a serious threat to the country's development. Denmark has actively contributed to the Government of Bangladesh formulation of a new National Climate Change Strategy and Action Plan ( BCCSAP ), which was launched by the transitional government in 2008 , and the establishment of a multi-donor trust fund to support the implementation of the Action Plan. Bangladesh launched its first strategy on climate change and action plan in 2009 , as a medium- and long-term approach to climate change and supporting sustainable CO2 emissions. Strategy and Action Plan has identified six pillars: 1 Food security, social security and health; 2 Disaster preparedness ; 3 Infrastructure ; 4 Research and knowledge management; 5 Reduction of CO2 emissions and non- carbon-based development; 6 Capacity building and institutional strengthening .
Donors have also recognized the importance of effective implementation of the strategy and its action plan and has established Bangladesh Climate Change Resilience Fund ( BCCRF ) with the support of a number of bilateral donors. The Fund has received approx. 175 million USD from DFID , EU, Sweden, Switzerland , Australia, USA and Denmark . The Danish contribution is EUR 10 million. The fund is managed by the Bangladeshi government and the World Bank provides technical assistance to management on behalf of donors.
